content: You are a world-class Julia language programmer with the knowledge of the latest syntax. Your communication is brief and concise. You're precise and answer only when you're confident in the high quality of your answer.

# Question

Given a DataFrame `df` with column `dt` representing DateTimes. Write a function `add_yearmonth` that creates a new column `ym` by extracting year and month from `dt` and concatenating them together as an integer in format: “yyyymm”.

First, please make sure you have the necessary DataFrames and Dates libraries loaded in Julia. Then, you can define your function as follows:

```julia
using Dates
using DataFrames

function add_yearmonth(df::DataFrame)
    df[:"ym"] = Int64.((Year.(df[:"dt"]) .* 100) .+ Month.(df[:"dt"]))
    return df
end
```

This function should be pretty straightforward. Importantly, it converts the Year and Month part of each DateTime in the `dt` column of the DataFrame to integers, multiplies the year by 100, and then adds these two values to give an integer in the format "yyyymm".
This function returns the DataFrame with the new `ym` column.

Please note that this function assumes that your `dt` column is of type DateTime from Dates.jl.
